children.value: Software Crafter building üå©Ô∏è cloud-based cellular IoT solutions at
Mentor. Speaker. Conference & Community builder. Camper. üèïÔ∏è üöê
You can find me on these sites.

Please note that I will reject connection requests from people I've never met
personally.

status.full_text: Good morning from a rainy #Trondheim üá≥üá¥. On my way to @nordictestdays to talk about firmware end-to-end testing using real hardware and GitHub actions! https://t.co/loKCZpbsAK
Already delayed, so let's see if I make the connection in Oslo. https://t.co/qowHWLtHYj
@Jen_BMJ Oh, that's cool! Enjoy!
Made it Stockholm! https://t.co/4Fv0a0LVbE
@Heimeshoff @hamotsi I found many of the answers already very meaningful.

TIL that if you are using Discord for private messaging, it leaks sensitive information about these conversations:
https://t.co/gDjsZ9KDBJ
Beautiful weather in #Stockholm üá∏üá™! https://t.co/mKRAMTgXgk
Arrived! #ntd2022 #tallinn üá™üá™ https://t.co/qfTlkzMeGp
@beriberikix @nordictestdays I expect that this year will be recorded as well: https://t.co/5Ph4lr0TyH
@OliverStenbom @nordictestdays üëãüèª Let's meet at the gate after leaving the plane.
The hotel has a SPA, so let's do some Sauna before the speakers dinner. #ntd2022 https://t.co/2oaXadBlxA
Great way to start a conference! I get a few @codefreeze_fi feels! #ntd2022 https://t.co/O6cQkPi8vd
That's an awesome location for #ntd2022! üòç https://t.co/zQNrf97wBI
https://t.co/1KrtOtDHg0
https://t.co/Dq9ikXlwce
We are getting the #Tallinn üá™üá™ city tour now. #ntd2022 https://t.co/qCTwQmz8gQ
https://t.co/HDRW9VlKce
This is St. Olaf's church, named after the Norwegian King Olaf, who is buried in Nidarosdomen in ... Trondheim! üá™üá™üá≥üá¥ https://t.co/Yjl3ozy6wy
https://t.co/uzseJTLwP2
https://t.co/IDhPLffCng
LOL (Germans will know.) https://t.co/EruGE6M6jZ
Now for some food! https://t.co/fATMGfAVwI
OMG the food here was amazing, and I got proper vegan dishes as well! https://t.co/Mg3Rj7O3bw
https://t.co/0DJO5MX9Kp
The toilets here are also pretty unique! https://t.co/1gdEb7WHCd
This is the bar Steve Balmer went to after Microsoft bought Skype. https://t.co/DzQ3EskZus
This is supposed to be a national monument of a drink: https://t.co/2yknafJ1u7

@NoraTSM Ah, I wasn't aware!
In German it's like a small pre school child would say it.
@gazebo_c @olafurw Grenadier. https://t.co/pCnlUvbe8M

@NMoutschen Yes! Absolutely amazing hosts, great food and drinks!
https://t.co/rGu5ExkDOk
@TonyBologni Not shopped: https://t.co/qoSS0gUQiG
@guna_lv I'm so excited for the conference!

@kohidave @clare_liguori I think CF is already great (in terms of what solves), but a feature I miss most is actually beyond its scope: time to deploy. Ideally it should deploy 100x faster.
Wish two would be support for deploying lambdas from Typescript without needing to figure out the packaging part.
Conference organizers, please put this on your CfP! https://t.co/wUCnIeq9M6
@w3ltraumpirat Can you show me where CDK does that today?
@praneetaprakash @kohidave @clare_liguori That bundles everything in one file. Which isn't awesome if I have many lambdas that share dependencies and I want to use layers.
First day of #ntd2022, starting with @elarlang's keynote: https://t.co/RknLtdYJUt https://t.co/Zc20orTqSp
It's important to analyse a bug for the potential impact, so the severity is understood by all stakeholders. #ntd2022 https://t.co/7brBNYeZXQ

@w3ltraumpirat My point exactly. CDK, and SAM are a start, but you still have to figure out a compilation pipeline when it goes beyond simple Lambdas that use built-in dependencies. It's debatable whether CF should solve that, but I think it would be a great feature.
@w3ltraumpirat Yes, I know. One small dev can still have dreams.
Coffee break ... This is such a cool venue! #ntd2022 https://t.co/Lpwg1Fi1Lz

@w3ltraumpirat AWS Lambda could provide at least one officially maintained toolchain, maybe even as a service. Because not only do you have to solve compilation and layering, but ideally also artifact re-use.
I wrote about my needs here: https://t.co/PTagFLpu0t

@w3ltraumpirat I am working on a newer version of that using esbuild.
It takes a lambda handler file and resolves all the npm dependencies and puts them in a layer, and bundles the dependencies from within the project in the lambda ZIP file (as ES modules): https://t.co/wJKBo4Uzlh

Now listening to Stefan Schenk who talks about mocking data for component testing in a React application.
https://t.co/R5nkUOtQid
#ntd2022 https://t.co/nBDtYIRTyv

@w3ltraumpirat I have to check out the V2 version of that construct. Usually CDK constructs don't support async code execution so having the build step in the place where the construct is created would be preferred for me, but hasn't been possible before.

In this talk @maros_kutschy compares two popular visual UI testing frameworks, @Applitools and @percy_io. #ntd2022 

Great introduction to both tools and their basic usage. https://t.co/9da71D4CCm
Lawful good. https://t.co/0ziKfDnIJA
Great to be in a session about communication at #ntd2022. Natalia Roma≈Ñska speaks about active listening. https://t.co/5Zf09N1xbn https://t.co/43vrLxUDiO

Great tips, also love the slides!
I often forget to paraphrase, and am pretty bad at mirroring. #ntd2022 https://t.co/EtA0rb91En
That slide is üî•! https://t.co/7SSOmOtVSg
Now the first workshop: testing asynchronous applications with Calvin Moore and @BlancheCarstens. #ntd2022 https://t.co/5X9lZ1BYge

So, I hope I encourage @BlancheCarstens to come out of her Twitter hiatus because she is trying to solve a massive problem in South Africa: giving school kids access to computers and the opportunity to learn about and with them. She's looking for ideas!

@BlancheCarstens Many schools don't have computers, mostly because the are getting stolen because they are very valuable. So one idea would be to distribute inexpensive micro:bits from @microbit_edu, but also they require computers or smartphones to program.

@BlancheCarstens @microbit_edu Would be interesting to learn from @teenscancode how they solve this issue.
They also work with the micro:bit: https://t.co/9ctdwe2S3L
And now it's time for the @nordictestdays #ntd2022 manel. https://t.co/b0roJ4Da5w

Holy shit, this intro!
https://t.co/8UExc6dWPy
Dinner time! #ntd2022 https://t.co/SpqA3Un6Hs
Party time! #ntd2022 https://t.co/sJ7FYGYves
@maaretp I especially love that you come to @SoCraTes_Conf!
Has someone already compared GitHub's Dependabot with @renovatebot for projects with NPM dependencies? https://t.co/ZpZgqLP9gM

In the next session @maros_kutschy  talks about automating UI testing.
Good to see BDD features being used here!
https://t.co/Siim98dboX #ntd2022 https://t.co/wtmEXe2CKm
@maaretp @SoCraTes_Conf I'm sure you will love it. And I am also excited for two of my junior colleagues who will join the foundation day and get to learn from you.

nRF Connect SDK 2.0.0 has been released and my personal highlight is the experimental support for LwM2M with @AVSystemCom as the endpoint. This will significantly reduce power consumption compared to TLS+MQTT, so check it out and help us make it stable.
https://t.co/aotcZtSVry

If you wonder, if I *really* wanted to call it out?
Yes, absolutely.
Everything we do as part of a conference is political, and even as an attendee (or speaker in my case) we have a choice what to do about this. Always. https://t.co/vmo6wqBMk6
Had this "juice" and it tasted like shit. And because this shitty system does not allow me to control the amount, a full glass went into the drain. https://t.co/DDIiTOvDBY

@NicolaLindgren @ron_werner says Hi!
This venue keeps on giving: https://t.co/Ouw4TTfa1d

So there is a CHILDREN'S book about #testing, created in #Finland üá´üáÆ by @kkakkonen and it's a beautiful hardcover that aims to teach children the fun of finding bugs and improving software. We need great testers, too, so definitely check it out! https://t.co/oQVCjoaMdN

@guna_lv @nordictestdays It's a great crowd. I am always happy when I am around people who invest time in themselves and come together to share and learn. @smokienorful does a great job of facilitating that!
https://t.co/6oLptkUWUC
https://t.co/j1Wo7GjlYN

They are discoing the right way:
#NTD2022 https://t.co/hU5w1ve8it
#NTD2022 after-party: https://t.co/WsfJ2JfaZR
Good night #NTD2022 https://t.co/QenJ9ihWbO
Totally worth the ‚Ç¨2,50. https://t.co/7Fzpz7wUZ7
It's completely made of small ice cream bubbles. Amazing! https://t.co/53Bfl3VYfv

@CorinnaBaldauf I use the same technique when facilitating a discussion. If a person wants to speak, I keep track of the order. I don't have a name for it, maybe FIFO queue (first first out). During the discussion I will mention that I've recognized a person's intention to speak.

@maaretp While I don't want to diminish the severity of attacking your legacy, I want to ensure that you have built a legacy of your own that stands for itself, without the (lack of) validation of any third party. That said, it is important to address efforts to minimize your works.
@kolencherry The most important fun fact: it's fun to eat, too!

Day 2 of #NTD2022.
Did a tech check this morning for my talk later.
Find me at 1410 in V√§ike Saal downstairs. https://t.co/C9BZrkawgT
Took a walk during the coffee break because the sun is out! This concrete monster is next to the #ntd2022 conference venue. https://t.co/WufBLUHeRV
Now hearing from @tomdrivendev how to set up teams for better quality: https://t.co/58qmj5JF8B #ntd2022 https://t.co/muIQBcNsmP
Teams should test together, not develop and do QA in separation. This also means a new role for testers: they need to become a quality advocate. https://t.co/ynHTs0AGkf
Now for something I've never worked with: testing video quality. Super interesting to see all these tools they need in action. @DenissLocmelis #NTD2022 https://t.co/Npt801x8zb
The tools: https://t.co/fzitLbTUoL
@foofighter75 Yes, that was highlighted on another slide: helping developers to get into a tester's mindset.
Excited now to be able to listen to @madisp who shares @Veriff's end-to-end testing strategy. #NTD2022 https://t.co/DttoQSycec
Ohh, all magic links should have literal magic in them! #NTD2022 https://t.co/qSZkIcAThS

E2E tests are slow, but try to be below 15 minutes, otherwise too many context switches happen for developers. You should monitor this and make sure everyone is aware of the goal! https://t.co/QrwNeUBVy7
Quite a few challenges with this approach, but the benefits are there! #NTD2022 https://t.co/edA1EZrdeI

I hope to catch an overview on how to visualize test results from @Anais_vanAsselt. #NTD2022 
https://t.co/rg1Z7XSizO https://t.co/jTffWGh0MR
These dashboards for visualizing test results can't be too technical, but should take the perspective of the business, so all involved parties can use that information. https://t.co/xQSjnBWsUB
Thanks #NTD2022 for having me! I had fun, also giving my talk! Thanks to all who made @nordictestdays possible! https://t.co/92CysJueRS

Already on the plane back! Goodbye #Tallinn üá™üá™

I forgot to mention that the Estonians just serve you melted cheese on a plate. Motherfucking genius! üá™üá™ ü§Ø

@emna__ayadi @elarlang Yes, it's very unique. Not your typical hotel conference center!

https://t.co/NMylO4JqpU is a very interesting deviation of JavaScripts model of code once run anywhere. For #IIoT it is acknowledged that not all targets can run the same code, so they are working on providing a way to formalize vendor-specific APIs in JavaScript. https://t.co/KDU7r587MX
Looking forward to watch the recording of this one! https://t.co/9iJvi2bMk8

@amokleben This effort is about the language features to allow direct hardware access (which often needs direct memory manpiulation), not about the implementation.
However, if you look at examples like @Espruino or @nodebots you will see that they run stripped down interpreters, because >
@amokleben @Espruino @nodebots runtimes like Google's V8 are 10-100 times too large for embedded devices.

@amokleben @Espruino @nodebots I'm looking forward to this talk: https://t.co/vTmz0Tdoio 
I expect that it will explain in detail what the benefits of adding new features to the standard for IoT devices are.
Yes, I'm a man. I stop reading at #5 and assume I'll ace the rest, too. https://t.co/BHgMlpYDH4
@madisp at his steampunk office at #ntd2022 https://t.co/j4jpCEgV0o

@beriberikix @nordictestdays Unfortunately only the track of the big stage was recorded, not all talks. So for now I can only share the slides with you: https://t.co/26ij4ofBwv
... let me know if you have any questions, not everything will be super clear without the audio track. I am planning a blog soon.
@emsuiko Uh, hope you get well soon!

My junior today asked for a recommendation how to document architecture. I don't have a good one, and I am again thinking about writing down how I want architecture to be documented: from the viewpoint of data that flows through it. It needs to be a dynamic, not arrows+boxes. https://t.co/gf1UuLbxPd
@m4nl5r Yeah, ideally I have per-feature test case sequence diagrams that include the actual data and the components it was handled by, including links to the infra definition in code.

@_Iyalei Yes, I like that. I want to start with the feature: "We want to store temperature data of devices, and be able to retrieve them later." ... then see the input and output data ... then see which "components" this data touches and how it is transformed in the process.
"Top Gun: Maverick" is a 131-minute long advertisement for death. https://t.co/NdNV3vpBZU

If you are at #ew22 don't miss the opportunity to speak to Chris and his team! https://t.co/AEwPFUHpDE

@stanislav What C4 is missing for me is the "glue": in AWS architecture a lot is happening on the "arrows" between boxes and C4 does not focus on that; it puts an emphasis on components, however in cloud native archtitecture the containers are boring, the implementation is in the glue.

Me: here is the tech challenge.
Them: *solves tech challenge quickly*.
My feedback: not fully implement, bugs, no tests. Care to fix?
Them: The provided solution should be sufficient to make an impression of my skills.

@ddprrt GitHub pages.

@femtoduino @JacobusSystems Sure, but none of that is the case here.
The challenge came after a 1,5 hour intro call.
The coding challenge has no time limit, and they only spent a few hours on it.
I've provided clear feedback within a day what is missing.
They would have had the chance to correct it.

@femtoduino @JacobusSystems Most candidates that went through this process were very happy with how it went, so I am confident that it's fair.

However, I am curious to learn what you personally consider appropriate to do for testing a candidate's technical abilites?

@femtoduino @JacobusSystems Yes, this is fully up to the candidates choice. I clearly state that they can suggest an alternative, and for some that can work (if they are allowed to shared a project they feel comfortable discussing).
@femtoduino @JacobusSystems But I understand the predicament. I think I will start asking (senior!) candidates to propose the way they would like to be assessed for their technical abilities.

@bitshiftmask @femtoduino @JacobusSystems Yeah, I know. However, I have many applicants from abroad, so we can't relocated them here on a hunch that they might perform well.
